fields.description:
In GIt, authors are usually identified in the form:
{panel}
    Graeme Mathieson <mathie@woss.name>
{panel}
just like an RFC822-formatted email address. Unfortunately, this causes a problem with the REST API, which spits out the author into an attribute of the <commit /> node without escaping the '<' character. This causes the Bamboo Confluence plugin (amongst others, I'm sure) to balk when trying to consume the XML from the REST API.

Here is a sample response from our Bamboo server, demonstrating the problem:
{panel}
<response>
        <build>
    <projectName>New Relic Dashboard</projectName>
    <buildName>Master Branch</buildName>
    <buildKey>NEWRELIC-MASTER</buildKey>
    <buildState>Successful</buildState>
    <buildNumber>10</buildNumber>
    <failedTestCount>0</failedTestCount>
    <successfulTestCount>5</successfulTestCount>
    <buildTime>2009-04-28 16:20:17</buildTime>
    <buildCompletedDate>2009-04-28T16:20:23+0000</buildCompletedDate>
    <buildDurationInSeconds>6</buildDurationInSeconds>
    <buildDurationDescription>6 seconds</buildDurationDescription>
    <buildRelativeBuildDate>1 day ago</buildRelativeBuildDate>
    <buildTestSummary>5 passed</buildTestSummary>
    <buildReason>Code has changed</buildReason>

    <commits>
                <commit author="Graeme Mathieson <mathie@woss.name>" />
    </commits>

    </build>
    <build>
    <projectName>New Relic Dashboard</projectName>
    <buildName>Master Branch</buildName>
    <buildKey>NEWRELIC-MASTER</buildKey>
    <buildState>Successful</buildState>
    <buildNumber>9</buildNumber>
    <failedTestCount>0</failedTestCount>
    <successfulTestCount>5</successfulTestCount>
    <buildTime>2009-04-28 16:05:05</buildTime>
    <buildCompletedDate>2009-04-28T16:05:10+0000</buildCompletedDate>
    <buildDurationInSeconds>5</buildDurationInSeconds>
    <buildDurationDescription>5 seconds</buildDurationDescription>
    <buildRelativeBuildDate>1 day ago</buildRelativeBuildDate>
    <buildTestSummary>5 passed</buildTestSummary>
    <buildReason>Code has changed</buildReason>

    <commits>
                <commit author="Graeme Mathieson *<mathie@woss.name>*" />
    </commits>

    </build>
    <build>
    <projectName>New Relic Dashboard</projectName>
    <buildName>Master Branch</buildName>
    <buildKey>NEWRELIC-MASTER</buildKey>
    <buildState>Successful</buildState>
    <buildNumber>8</buildNumber>
    <failedTestCount>0</failedTestCount>
    <successfulTestCount>5</successfulTestCount>
    <buildTime>2009-04-25 09:16:51</buildTime>
    <buildCompletedDate>2009-04-25T09:16:57+0000</buildCompletedDate>
    <buildDurationInSeconds>5</buildDurationInSeconds>
    <buildDurationDescription>5 seconds</buildDurationDescription>
    <buildRelativeBuildDate>5 days ago</buildRelativeBuildDate>
    <buildTestSummary>5 passed</buildTestSummary>
    <buildReason>Manual build</buildReason>

    <commits>
    </commits>

    </build>
    <build>
    <projectName>New Relic Dashboard</projectName>
    <buildName>Master Branch</buildName>
    <buildKey>NEWRELIC-MASTER</buildKey>
    <buildState>Successful</buildState>
    <buildNumber>7</buildNumber>
    <failedTestCount>0</failedTestCount>
    <successfulTestCount>5</successfulTestCount>
    <buildTime>2009-04-24 11:54:42</buildTime>
    <buildCompletedDate>2009-04-24T11:54:47+0000</buildCompletedDate>
    <buildDurationInSeconds>5</buildDurationInSeconds>
    <buildDurationDescription>5 seconds</buildDurationDescription>
    <buildRelativeBuildDate>5 days ago</buildRelativeBuildDate>
    <buildTestSummary>5 passed</buildTestSummary>

                <commit author="Graeme Mathieson *<mathie@woss.name>*" />
    </commits>

</response>

fields.summary: REST API not correctly escaping '<' characters in the author attribute of a commit

fields.description:
If a shared working copy is used among dependent plans it can happen that commits have occurred before the last dependent plan has been executed.
Then a parent build of the next revision is queued and executed before the dependent plans of revision n-1. As we are looking at a shared working copy the sources for dependent plans become inconsistent. The parent plan has updated the working copy to revision n where as the dep plans need revision n-1.

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-1780
fields.summary: keep sequence of builds atomic for shared working copies

fields.description: If an exception occurs on the server side, the listener doesn't seem to accept any more messages
fields.summary: ActiveMQ services will stop in case of exception

fields.description:
if there is a win registry entry
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Command Processor and its AutoRun property is to execute cd \
then the builder (ant) will be started in c:\ or d:\ instead of in the correct working copy directory path - and the builder will not find the files it is looking for.

Bamboo should make sure that the builder/build script is executed in the right directory. ATM bamboo assumes that there are not default commands run when a command shell is opened.

This directory is known to bamboo - for example
Starting to build 'TESTCI - TESTCIPLAN'
... running command line: D:\devtools\apache-ant-1.7.1\bin\ant.bat -f build.xml -debug build
... *in : D:\Bamboo\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\TESTCI-TESTCIKEY\build*
... using java.home: D:\devtools\Java\jdk1.5.0_17 

A good place to read about the registry setting for the command shell : http://www.msfn.org/board/lofiversion/index.php/t45360.html
fields.summary: Bamboo starts builder in wrong directory in command shell in windows if HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Command Processor is set

fields.description: Please display and log the username when build plans are changed -- created, disabled, and reenabled. Knowing  who made a change will allow build plans that cause infrastructure failures, and thus a cascade of other failures, to be managed.
fields.summary: Log build plan changes (enable/disable) against a username

fields.description:
The system requirements for Bamboo haven't been reviewed in a while:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Installation+Guide

They probably should be fleshed out... the JIRA system requirements are a good guide:
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/requirements.html
fields.summary: Review Bamboo system requirements

fields.description:
Currently if you want to see the Clover HTML coverage reports you need to manually setup an artifact definition to bring the HTML files back to the server.  The report is than available on the Artifacts tab as opposed to the Clover tab - doh !!

- Want to see the Clover HTML reports on the Build Results Clover tab. 
- This is involves:
 -- enter the Clover HTML directory as seen by the agent in build config (next to the location for the clover XML report)
  -- create a corresponding artifact definition.
  -- update the build results clover tab to include the link to the HTML reports.

It would make some sense to have this artifact definiton "not modifiable" by users.  If the HTML file location is changed in the build config tab then the corresponding artifact defn must be changed.
fields.summary: Make the Clover HTML reports easier to setup

fields.description: This page is generally slow to load, it has a lot of data to retrieve.  The more plans there are the longer it will take.  It would be good if we can look into improving the way it does data collection, the way the data is stored or even the way it is displayed to improve the performance of this page.
fields.summary: Improve performance of Agent Matrix page.

fields.description: Jira logs all system properties and environment information every time it starts up.  This would help support if Bamboo did something similar.  It just needs to print out everything that is in the system info page.
fields.summary: More logging on Bamboo start up

fields.description:
The symptom:

2009-04-22 12:56:29,747 ERROR [TP-Processor2] [runtime] 
Expected hash. currentlyBuilding evaluated instead to freemarker.template.SimpleScalar on line 121, column 35 in fragments/showBuildQueue.ftl.
The problematic instruction:
----------
==> if !currentlyBuilding.executableElasticImages.isEmpty() [on line 121, column 29 in fragments/showBuildQueue.ftl]
----------


The cause:

On line 114 f the showBuildQueue.ftl file we set currentlyBuilding to ' ' if it isn't found, but forget on line 121 to check if it has any content before calling the methods on it.

As an aside, I am not sure if we really should be setting what is supposed to be another object (something that isn't a string) to an empty string rather than just leaving it null...

fields.summary: NPE when upgrading if out of service period

fields.description:
It would be great to have the queue time (BuildResultsSummary.getQueueTime()) and the VCS update time (BuildResultsSummary.getVcsUpdateTime()) available via the REST API.  

An added bonus would be the "average" queue time for a given plan.  There is already Build.getAverageBuildDuration which returns the average from the last 10 builds.  Maybe we could return the average queue time over the last 10 builds.
fields.summary: Expose Build Queue time and VCS update time via REST

fields.description:
Source Depot is based on Perforce, but isn't perforce.  The known compatability problem at the moment is that SourceDepot looks out for different system properties than Perforce (e.g SDPORT vs P4PORT), but all the commands run should still be the same.   

Basic support for this repository can probably/possibly be achieved by tweaking our perforce library to also set the SourceDepot properties as well as the perforce properties. 

There is a workaround at the moment to just set the system properties outside of Bamboo, however this restricts the entire server to the same SourceDepot server.
fields.summary: Support for Source Depot repository

fields.description: A lot of the time when you cut and paste a Bamboo license it doesn't get accepted by Bamboo because of strange hidden characters.  It would be cool if Bamboo could strip these out for the user.
fields.summary: Adding a license should strip any strange carriage return characters.

fields.description:
I would like more control over the builders and the builder queues so that I could do things like:

1. Have builder queues disabled on startup so that configuration changes be done without having builds start in the middle of those changes.

2. Have the ability to stop the build queue from dequeuing jobs so that a orderly shutdown be done once all jobs are completed.

3. Have the ability to automatically shutdown Bamboo once all current jobs are completed.
fields.summary: Better control over builders and build queue needed
Document how to use NTLM authentication with SVN repository

fields.description: On the artifacts tab, for a build results there is a "remove all artifacts" link.  This does not ask for confirmation, and it is easy to accidentally click.
fields.summary: "Remove All Artifacts" link should require confirmation

fields.description: When expiring builds, on each build it deletes it re-indexes the builds either side of it.  This seems unnecessary as there is a pretty good chance some of those builds are about to get deleted as well.  Perhaps a better solution is to delete all the build results first and then perform the indexing tasks.
fields.summary: Build Expiry performs unnecessary build indexing.

fields.description: At approx 14:33 23/04/2009 CDT BEAC stopped taking builds off the queue even thou there were agents free to accept those builds.

fields.description: Potentially there are a number of agents scattered around a network; it would be useful to have a list of agents whose bootstrap jar is out of date, ideally with a hostname or IP attached.
fields.summary: UI showing Agents whose bootstrap jar is out of date

fields.description: The specific use case is for upgrades to bootstrap jars. Every now and then, the bootstrap jar may need to upgrade. In this scenario, it would be good to have a list on the Bamboo UI to at least indicate the agents that tried to connect, but failed due to bootstrap jar mis-match.
fields.summary: Display a list of agents that attempted to connect to the server but failed

fields.description: Bamboo has been set up to use various Environment variables rather than setting them through the UI.  However, the validation code will complain if you leave the client field or the port field blank.  Instead the validation code should try and find system properties if they user leaves the UI empty.  And then complain if it can't find the system variables either.
fields.summary: Perforce configuration doesn't use system variables during validation for client and port

fields.description:
When you clone a plan the user doing the cloning automatically gains admin rights for that plan.  Meaning that they can edit the permissions and provide further access to things.   
If a user clones a build which they don't have admin rights to, they should not be given admin rights in the new plan.  (I.e the permissions tab should be hidden from them during create and edit modes).

fields.description:
I've added the Pre-Post Build Command Plugin to my Bamboo server and had a few issues, commented on here:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMEXT/Pre-Post+Build+Command+Plugin

Now, when using this plugin, the Builder sub-tab of the Configuration tab for every build shows the following error and none of the normal settings:

Builder plugin not found for plan!

Selecting Edit Plan at that point goes to the normal edit page and all the settings seem to be preserved and correct; they just do not display as normal on the review page.

I realize there is only so much that can be done about third party plugins, but I don't think the basic Bamboo build review functionality should be affected by a (possibly) poorly behaving plugin.
fields.summary: "Builder plugin not found for plan!" when using Pre-Post Build Command Plugin
Use the pdk plugin to redploy plugins 2 plugins

fields.description: For some reason the fix from: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-2986 never was checked into head.
fields.summary: Regression:  ConglomerateCookieValue on Dashboard

fields.description:
(for want of a better summary...)

When a remote agent picks up a build of the queue, it may fail in reading the message (e.g. if it can't download classes from the server due to an export).  If this happens the agent will die and has not been able to tell the server that it has taken the build.  Thus the build gets stuck in the "in queue" state in Bamboo when its technically not in the queue.

Chai mentioned that there may be an error jms queue we can add messages that fail to, so they can be detected and dealt with accordingly.
fields.summary: Improve the error handling of jms exceptions

fields.description: This logic seems to have gotten lost at some stage.  This can cause discrepancies in builds because remote agents can have trouble communicating during export, if we prevent builds from happening the remote agents might be okay and builds not lost.
fields.summary: Build queues are no longer disabled during export

fields.description: If the change list parsing fails due to strange syntax, Bamboo get stuck for that plan because it can never get past the failing change list.  We need to change Bamboo better handle these syntax errors.   Perhaps we could try and skip that changelist that fails or something so that life can go on and only that one build/change is stuffed.
fields.summary: Change the way perforce change list parsing handles errors

fields.description:
When parsing change lists the perforce library checks the line beginnings for specific key words.  If someone puts on of these key words in the description then Bamboo thinks its the beginning of the new section rather than still part of the description.  This is because the library strips automatically stripes the tabs off the front of each line.

Attached is an example changelist which will fail.
fields.summary: Perforce changelist parsing can not differentiate between description lines and other lines

fields.description:
We have occasional builds that hang (apparently) because the build logging information from the agent is no longer communicated to the server even though the build is still running, the agent is still connected, etc. We have long running builds and the lack of logging triggers the hung build event, but the build on the agent is actually still running and runs to completion. It even appears that the agent successfully runs the post-build tasks such as transferring artifacts, but the server status remains hung with no log updates and never "finishes" the build.

Last night we had this happen to four builds at once. In the attached bamboo.log file, at 2009/04/16 18:23:15 you can see four builds all trigger the hung build detection at the same time. We have a 60 minute limit on that, so it was about one hour earlier when the logging stopped, which we saw in the build activity pages and the download-data\build_logs. In the agent logs, you can see a long heartbeat message around 17:23, but our heartbeat timeout on the server is 240s, so the agents remained "attached".

It's probably worth pointing out that all of these machines are Hyper-V virtual machines and occasionally subject to strange behavior depending on the physical host. In this case, though, the agents that hung were spread across two different virtualization servers, so it seems more likely the problem originated on the server and/or its VM.

Please ignore the extra attachments (can't remove). Everything is in the zip file.
fields.summary: Builds hang when agent stops capturing build log

fields.description:
From BSP-1714.

When editing the configuration of a build, the overall Save/Done and Cancel buttons sometimes do not behave as first expected. Firstly, it feels like the entire plan configuration is being edited since switching tabs is performed without refreshing the page, yet the overall Save/Done and Cancel buttons actually belong to each tab, and cause the page to be refreshed when they are used. On the Requirements and Notifications tabs, the Cancel button actually disappears altogether.

The Artifacts tab has a particularly bad UI. Although there is a Cancel button, it does not roll back changes already made by clicking the "Save" link where new artifacts have been added - these seem to have been permanently persisted by then. Similarly, clicking the overall "Done" button on the Artifacts screen does not save the details of any new artifact which only exists in the textboxes where the "Save" link has not been clicked. Having both the "Save" link and a "Done" button is confusing.

It feels like the entire plan configuration should be edited in one operation (though still split across multiple tabs) rather than each tab being submitted separately. Making plan changes atomically rather than in units of tabs would also prevent builds being triggered while someone is in the middle of making configuration changes across multiple tabs. So there would be overall, static Save and Cancel buttons which apply to all changes made across all tabs and are always visible. Nothing would be saved until the Save button was clicked, including artifact changes, requirements, and everything else which currently has its own immediate persistence semantics - exactly like the support system I am using to submit this issue, where there are 3 tabs and static "Create" and "Cancel" buttons.
fields.summary: One universal Save/Cancel operation for all tabs under edit build configuration
Ability to enable/disable a whole plugin

fields.description:
# What were *my* code changes to this build?
#* I currently have to scan a list to locate these.  It would be better if only my changes were presented in the notification.
#* If the list is long, I have to click-through the e-mail notification to examine the whole list.  It would be better if all of my changes were provided in the e-mail notification.
fields.summary: Highlight my changes in notification emails

fields.description:
Even using the existing notification filtering options, developers still receive many notifications that are probably not relevant to them.  Each of these notifications is a distraction, and takes time and mental effort to diagnose.

We can improve developer productivity by filtering more intelligently, so that developers see fewer notifications, and by presenting notifications and build results pages in a way that lets developers more easily extract the information relevant to them.

Every time I receive a build result notification, I want the answers to the following questions:

# -What were *my* code changes to this build?-
#* -I currently have to scan a list to locate these.  It would be better if only my changes were presented in the notification.-
#* -If the list is long, I have to click-through the e-mail notification to examine the whole list.  It would be better if all of my changes were provided in the e-mail notification.- Tracked separately BAM-3772.
# *Only if I contributed code changes,* what are the new test failures?
#* I'm rarely interested in this if I haven't made a commit.
# Even if I made no code changes, which tests have been fixed *after first failing in a build to which I contributed changes*?
# *Only if I contributed code changes,* which tests are continuing to fail *after first failing in a build to which I contributed changes*?
#* I need to know about the bugs that I introduced.  I'm less interested in bugs that others introduced.

Notifications and build results pages should be presented in a way that highlights the answers to these questions.  If the answers to all of these questions is "nothing", then I shouldn't be distracted with a notification.

This idea could be further refined by allowing a set of consecutive failures of a single test to have "watchers".  By default, watchers would be anyone who made a relevant commit, but individuals could opt in and out, or add others.
fields.summary: Improvements to notification filtering and presentation to reduce developer distraction and effort

{noformat}

Anyway - Fedora 10 (the current stable) is publicly available since 2008-11-25 (since almost 5 months):
* [http://fedoraproject.org/en/]
* [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fedora_(operating_system)]
* [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Releases/10/Schedule]
whereas Fedora 8 was released on 2007-10-08 - about 1.5 year ago:
* [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Releases/8/Schedule]
and exactly this one is the installed Fedora version on the default AMI for Bamboo 2.2.1:
{noformat}
[root@domU-12-31-39-03-75-B2 bamboo-ebs]# cat /etc/fedora-release
Fedora release 8 (Werewolf)
{noformat}

What's more - Fedora 11 (current unstable version) - is scheduled to be released as stable on 2009-05-26:
[http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Releases/11/Schedule]

Summing up - if my build needs some additional / upgraded libraries which are not present in F8, but are in F10, then on each EC2 instace's start-up I would need to do the upgrade.
This is not wise in terms of EC2 cost reduction, as it just unnecessarily takes CPU time.

I know currently - in B2.2.1 you - can't use other AMIs than the default one (see also BAM-3756 for a request to customize the AMI used).
But if you happen to create another AMI based on this request (and assuming BAM-3756 not being resolved) should I just take next milestone release of Bamboo to use the new AMI which ID would be just hardcoded in the release?

Cheers!
Krystian Nowak

fields.description:
The SAL Authentication interfaces are based on oauth and we can not implement them fully until OAUTH goes into Bamboo.

Some notes:
They require the authenticator interface implementation (in the oauth plugin)
They require the oauth filter (also in the plugin).

If we want to use the default seraph implementation of these interfaces we need to alter our current login filter we use to do all the stuff the seraph BaseLoginFilter does.

Also som docs on how to test oauth = https://studio.atlassian.com/wiki/display/AG/OAuth+integration+testing
and there is also a sal-oauth consumer plugin in the OAUTH project as well.

fields.description:
Not all capabilities can be applied to an instance just by attaching ESB storage.
Some changes might be necessary to the OS itself.
It can be made now by executing yum install something when an instance starts up, but it takes time and sometimes also human interaction is needed.
So other images than the default one (ami-3c3dda55 in case of 2.2.1) could be allowed by providing AMI's ID.
